public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String s, Image i) {
public static DialogBox getDukeDialog(String s, Image i) {
* A GUI for Duke using FXML.
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
* Represents the chatbot that is able to respond to commands given by the user.
* An Alex object corresponds to a chatbot represented by a string referring to the
* data file where the bot will load the list of tasks from.
* Allows the user to input a command for the chatbot to respond to.
* Handles all the commands given by the user.
* If the chatbot does not understand the command, it will ask the user to try again.
return "Sorry, I don't understand that command. Did you make a typo?";
* Represents the storage where the list of tasks are stored. A Storage object corresponds to
* an inventory represented by strings referring to the directory and the data file.
* Creates a directory if the directory doesn't exist.
* Returns the list of tasks that are in the specified file.
* Saves the current list of tasks into the specified file.
* Creates a new file if the file doesn't exist.
System.err.println("Error reading tasks from file: " + ee.getMessage());
* Returns string representing whether the method succeeded or failed.
* Saves the current list of tasks into the specified file.
System.err.println("Error writing tasks to file: " + e.getMessage());
* Represents an action to be done by a certain date. A Deadline object corresponds to
* a piece of work represented by a string e.g., read book by Sunday
* Returns a string that has the format to be saved in the file.
* @return string to be saved as data.
* Returns a string that has the format to be shown to the user.
* @return string to be displayed to users.
return "[D][" + getStatusIcon() + "] " + super.toString() + " // by: " + dueDate.format(DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM d yyyy")) ;
* Represents an action to be done during a certain time period. An Event object corresponds to
* a piece of work represented by a string e.g., read book from 1st september 2024 to 4th september 2024
public Event(String description, LocalDate startDate, LocalDate endDate) {
* Returns a string that has the format to be saved in the file.
* @return string to be saved as data.
* Returns a string that has the format to be shown to the user.

* Represents an action to be done. A Task object corresponds to
* a piece of work represented by a string e.g., read book
* Returns a string based on whether the task is completed.

* Marks the task as not completed.
* Returns a string that has the format to be saved in the file.
* @return string to be saved as data.
* Returns a string that has the format to be shown to the user.
* @return string to be displayed to users.
* Represents an action to be done, with no time element included. A To-do object corresponds to
* a piece of work represented by a string e.g., read book
* Returns a string that has the format to be shown to the user.
* @return string to be displayed to users.
* Represents the list of tasks to be done. A TaskList object corresponds to
* a list of actions represented by an arraylist.
* Displays the list of tasks when commanded by the user.
reply = "Here are the tasks in your list: ";
* Displays the desired task as marked when commanded by the user.
* @param input input entered by the user
reply = "Nice! I've marked this task as done: \n" +
reply = "It seems that task does not exist. Please try again.";
* Displays the desired task as unmarked when commanded by the user.

reply = "OK, I've marked this task as not done yet: \n" +
reply = "It seems that task does not exist. Please try again.";

* Displays the task as added into the list.

reply = "You missed out some details. Try again";
reply = "Got it. I've added this task: \n" + todo.toString()
+ "\n Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list.";

reply = "Invalid date entered. Use this format: YYYY-MM-DD";

reply = "You missed out the details of the event task. Try again";
reply = "You missed out some details. Try again";
Event event = new Event(task, startDate, endDate);
reply = "Got it. I've added this task: \n" + event.toString()
+ "\n Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks in the list.";
reply = "Invalid date(s) entered. Use this format: YYYY-MM-DD";
* Deletes the desired task from the list when commanded by the user.

* @param input input entered by the user
reply = "OK, I've deleted this task: \n" + task.toString() +
"\n Now you have " + list.size() + " tasks left in the list.";
